itemDescription: English rugby league footballer and coach

wikipedia_page.main: James "Jim"/"Jimmy" Jolley (birth unknown – death unknown) was an English professional rugby league footballer who played in the 1900s and 1910s, and coached in the 1900s and 1910s. He played at representative level for Great Britain and England, and at club level for Warrington (Heritage Nº 84), Runcorn RFC and Leigh (Heritage № 204), as a stand-off, i.e. number 6, and coached at club level for Leigh, where he was the club's first coach.

response: In 1909, Mather Lane was upgraded when the embankment on the popular side was extended and raised giving the ground a capacity of 20,000 spectators. Around this time Leigh named its first coach – Jim Jolley. Over the next few years, Leigh had little success and crowd numbers dropped dramatically.
